journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Optimum path synthesis of a four-link mechanism with rolling contacts

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, De Lin Institute of Technology, No. 1 Lane 380, Qingyan Road, Tucheng 236, New Taipei City, Taiwan, Republic of China. email: wylin@mail.dlit.edu.tw

corresp.italic: Department of Mechanical Engineering, De Lin Institute of Technology, No. 1 Lane 380, Qingyan Road, Tucheng 236, New Taipei City, Taiwan, Republic of China. email: wylin@mail.dlit.edu.tw

article-meta.issue-title: INCLUDES A SPECIAL SECTION ON ADVANCED MATERIALS ENGINEERING: SELECTED PAPERS FROM THE INDO-AUSTRIAN SYMPOSIUM 2010

abstract.p: Kinematic synthesis problems of a four-link mechanism with rolling contacts have been studied in the literature. One may imagine a very difficult synthesis problem, which is much more difficult to solve for a seven-target-point problem. In fact, the kinematic synthesis formulation for a four-link mechanism with rolling contacts discussed in the literature is complicated by the improper selection of the design variables, which leads to simultaneous increases in the number of design variables and in the number of synthesis equations. Thus, in this work, an improved formulation for the kinematic synthesis of the four-link mechanism with rolling contacts is proposed where the GA–DE hybrid evolutionary algorithm is applied to solve the optimum path synthesis problem. Three examples are studied to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed model. The findings show that the present formulation can reduce the number of design variables for a seven-target-points synthesis problem by 10 when compared with that using the previous formulation discussed in the literature. This reduces the difficulty of a seven-target-point synthesis problem. More accurate results for all examples can be obtained only with the GA–DE algorithm. Thus, the proposed formulation is superior to the previous one discussed in the literature.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p:
The kinematic synthesis of pin-jointed four-bar mechanisms has been extensively studied. Of late, the path synthesis of a four-link mechanism with rolling contacts, as shown in Fig. 1, has been studied by Lee and Tsai [1]. The motion and function syntheses of a four-link mechanism with rolling contacts have been studied by Sheu et al. [2]. In fact, the process of problem formulation used in references [1] and [2] is nearly identical. Figure 1
A four-link mechanism with rolling contacts

The mechanism can grasp an object through rolling contacts. Links 2 and 4, hinged at the ground link (Link 1), serve as grippers. A cylindrical object (Link 3) with a radius r is gripped by the two links. The contacts between the grippers and the object are assumed to be pure rolling contacts. The mobility of the four-link mechanism with rolling contacts is one, because a rolling contact is a full joint. Lee and coauthors proposed a kinematic synthesis formulation for the four-link mechanism with rolling contacts and applied the formulation to the path synthesis problem [1] and to motion and function generation problems [2]. Chen [3] has described many gripping mechanisms containing linkage, gear, cam, screw, and flexible band types. Several types of versatile grippers including inflatable, soft-finger, and three-fingered gripper have also been presented. Chen [4] studied the kinetic characteristics of grippers for industrial robots, including the determination of the input–output forces of the grippers and calculations of gripping force for different combinations of gripper posture and workpiece orientation. Chen and Kumar [5] studied the kinematics and workspace of a three-mobility mechanism having two robot arms, which grasped an object through rolling contacts. Ceccarelli et al. [6] proposed an optimum dimensional synthesis for a gripping mechanism of linkage type (a four-bar linkage with two ternary links directly connected to the actuator through a rod as described in reference [6]). The optimization problem is formulated as an objective function describing the main grasping performance (transmitting the actuator force to the grasper to obtain a suitable grasping force) and constraints prescribing design requirements and mechanism peculiarities (guiding the grasper to a suitable location to obtain a suitable grasping configuration).

sec.title: 2 DISCUSSION
sec.p: As mentioned earlier, Lee and Tsai pioneered the study of the path synthesis of the four-link mechanism with rolling contacts. They derived the so-called path-incremental equations as design equations for this mechanism using the complex number expression. The number of traced target points versus the number of free choices for design variables is also discussed. Five-target-point and seven-target-point synthesis problems are studied using a two-phase method. The two-phase method utilizes the sequential quadratic programming algorithm to first solve the synthesis equations. Then, the Newton–Raphson method is used with the first-phase solution as the initial guess to obtain a more accurate solution. For a synthesis problem consisting of five target points on a smooth curve (Example 1), they obtained a quite accurate solution. However, a synthesis problem consisting of seven target points on a smooth curve was found to be far more difficult to solve, since the number of nonlinear equations increased to 24. Thus, the same smooth curve is used in Example 3 as in Example 1, while the two target points between the second and third points and between the fourth and fifth points are increased to form a seven-target-point problem. The 18 values for the design variables obtained in Example 1 are utilized for the initial estimate for the seven-target-point problem. Under such conditions, only six more newly estimated values are needed to run the optimization procedure. They obtained a more accurate solution than that obtained in Example 1.

After reading that pioneering work, one may have an image of a very difficult synthesis problem, since a seven-target-point synthesis problem is far too difficult to solve. However, after careful inspection one may find that this difficulty arises from their formulation. There are two disadvantages in that pioneering study. First, the formulation complicates the problem due to improper selection of the design variables. Note that the angular displacements of Links 2 and 3 may be obtained, if the angular displacement of Link 4 is prescribed. However, they considered the angular displacements of Links 2, 3, and 4 as the design variables. This complicated the problem because the number of design variables and the number of path-incremental equations increase with an increasing number of target points. For example, the number of design variables and the number of synthesis equations for the seven-precision-point problem are 25 and 24, respectively. Lastly, their formulation does not directly give information about the positions of the two pivots. Thus, an improved formulation is proposed in this work. In this study, the path synthesis problem is considered a mechanism optimization to minimize the objective function of position variations. The GA–DE hybrid algorithm [7, 8] is applied to solve the mechanism optimization problem. Three examples are examined to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed formulation.

sec.title: 3.1 Position equations
sec.p:
Figure 2 depicts a stick diagram and all the geometric parameters of the four-link mechanism with rolling contacts, where C and P are the circular centre of Link 3 and the coupler point, respectively. The solid lines in Fig. 2 denote the first position where the coupler point coincides with the first target point, and the dashed lines denote the ith position where the coupler point coincides with the ith target point. The symbols θ4i and θ2i are the angles for Links 4 and 2, respectively. Angle θ4i = θ41 + Δθ4i serves as the input angle. The angular displacement of Link 3 Δθ3i between the ith and first positions is defined to be positive in the clockwise rotation and may be expressed as (1)
where β2i and β4i are the angular displacements of Link 3 relative to Links 2 and 4, respectively, and defined to be positive in the clockwise rotation. Figure 2

Using the vector-loop equations for point C in the coordinate system O2XrYr, one may have

If the values of L21, L41, r, θ41, θ21, Δθ4i, and L1 are known, the values of β2i and β4i may be solved using the Newton–Raphson method for equations (6) and (7), with the help of equations (2), (4), and (5). The initial guesses for β22 and β42 are 0.0 and 0.0, respectively, and the initial guesses for β2i and β4i(i > 2) are β2(i - 1) and β4(i - 1), respectively. The convergence criteria are |f1|< 10−14 and |f2| < 10−14. When the values of β2i and β4i are obtained, the values of Δθ2i (or θ2i = θ21 + Δθ2i), φi, L4i, and L2i can also be obtained from Eqs. (2) to (4).

sec.title: 3.2 Design variables
sec.p:
There are N + 8 design variables for a path synthesis problem of N target points without prescribed timing to be optimized: x0, y0, θ0, L1, r, LP, φ1, L41, and θ4i (i = 1 − N). Design variable vector X is given as follows: (10)
Note that if these design variables are prescribed, the values of L21 and θ21 can be obtained very straightforward from the geometry of the first position. From the position equations and the design variables, one may obtain the number of free choices of design variables. They are listed in Table 1 and can be compared with the results of Lee and Tsai [1]. The present formulation can reduce the number of design variables for a seven-target-points synthesis problem by 10 when compared with that obtained by Lee and Tsai [1]. This reduces the difficulty of the problem and leads to obtaining more satisfactory solutions. Table 1.
The number of target points versus the number of free design variables for path generation

sec.title: 3.3 Design objective
sec.p: The position error is defined as the sum of the square of the Euclidean distance between each Pdi and the corresponding Pi, where {Pdi} is the set of positions of target points (indicated by the designer); and {Pi} is the set of the positions of coupler points of the synthesized mechanism for a set of input angles {θ4i}. They can be written in the world coordinate system as Pdi=[PXdi,PYdi]T and Pi=[PXi,PYi]T , respectively.
The synthesis problem for the four-link mechanism with rolling joints is to minimize the position error considered as the objective function, which may be expressed by

sec.title: 4 GA–DE HYBRID EVOLUTIONARY ALGORITHM
sec.p: The GA–DE hybrid evolutionary algorithm is discussed in references [7] and [8]. For completeness, it is briefly described in this section. A population with randomly generated chromosomes is initialized. Each chromosome (individual) is a candidate solution. The quality of the individual is estimated by the fitness value. Roulette-wheel selection is used to allow those individuals with higher fitness to have a higher chance of being selected. Thereafter, two individuals are paired randomly as parents. Offspring are generated using genetic operators, differential vector perturbation, and mutation, from either one or two individuals. The technique of elitism [9] is used.

Here, genes xi (i = 1 - n) represent n variables encoded in terms of real numbers that fall between their bounds. All genes are grouped in a vector X that represents a chromosome, that is (12)
(13)

sec.title: 4.1 Initialization
sec.p: An initial population with Np chromosomes is randomly generated. The gene in each chromosome is given by
where γ is a random real number between 0 and 1.

sec.title: 4.2 Differential vector perturbations
sec.p: The differential vector perturbation of DE, with the best individual or some excellent individuals as the disturbed vectors, is used to replace the crossover operation in the real-valued genetic algorithm. Therefore, parents are used as differential vectors, not for the crossover operation. All parents are randomly divided into k groups corresponding to the top k individuals, denoted by Xtop1, Xtop2 ...,Xtopk. The value of k is a user-defined integer. In the ith group, the offspring may be generated by

where Xr1 and Xr2 are the parents. Random and different values for r1 and r2, in addition to some excellent individuals used as the disturbed vectors, may be considered another way of maintaining population diversity.

A main perturbation rate Pm1 is defined as the ratio of the expected number of offspring generated by differential vector perturbations to the total population size, while replacing crossover rate Pc in the real-valued genetic algorithm.

sec.title: 4.3 Mutation
sec.p: Here, mutation is performed to replace an entire, randomly selected chromosome with random real numbers (that are within the limits of variables). The minor perturbation rate Pm2, i.e. mutation rate, is defined as the ratio of the expected number of offspring introduced by mutation to the total population size.

sec.title: 5 NUMERICAL EXAMPLES
sec.p: The effectiveness of the proposed formulation is verified by studying three examples from the literature. The user-supplied parameters for the GA–DE hybrid evolutionary algorithm for the present problem are mainly based on those utilized in reference [7] as follows: size of population Np = 400; top four individuals as the disturbed vectors, i.e. k = 4; number of generations Gmax = 1000; major perturbation rate Pm1 = 0.6; and minor perturbation rate Pm2 = 0.01. The GA–DE algorithm generally has a very good exploitation capability. However, the GA–DE algorithm often suffers from premature convergence in some difficult problems. There are three schemes for increasing the population diversity or exploration capability of the GA–DE algorithm: (1) increasing the population size; (2) using certain excellent individuals as the disturbed vectors; and (3) using a large initial population size or a large population size for early generations. The first and second schemes are utilized in this work. Ten to 50 repeated runs in an example are executed to find satisfactory results. The examples studied are based on the assumption that the frictions between member 3 and members 2 and 4 are sufficient. In fact, an inequality constraint should be considered when the frictional condition is prescribed. The constraint is that the angle between the two radial lines must be greater than a necessary minimum, measured counterclockwise from the radial line for Link 4 to that for Link 2. The radial line for Link 4 is defined by connecting the centre of Link 3 to the contact point of Links 3 and 4. Similarly, the radial line for Link 2 is defined by connecting the centre of Link 3 to the contact point of Links 3 and 2.

sec.title: 5.1 Synthesis of five target points on a smooth curve
sec.p: The first example was studied by Lee and Tsai [1]. They let the radius r be 1.5.
Design variables: X= [x0, y0, θ0, L1, Lp, φ1, L41, θ41, θ42, θ43, θ44, θ45]
Limits of the variables:

The synthesized design variables and the objective function value are shown in Table 2. The present results are more accurate than that obtained using the sequential quadratic programming algorithm or the Newton–Raphson method with the first-phase solution as the initial guess, as obtained by Lee and Tsai [1]. The kinematic stick diagram for the five target points is shown in Fig. 3. The evolution of the objective function value of the best-so-far individual corresponding to the number of generations is shown in Fig. 4. Smaller objective function values for the other 50 repeated runs such as 1.39 × 10− 7 and 9.72 × 10− 8 may be obtained. A larger population size Np = 800 and/or a larger generation Gmax = 2000 may not lead to a much more accurate solution. Figure 3
Kinematic stick diagram for Example 1

sec.title: 5.2 Synthesis of five target points distributed along a looped curve
sec.p: This difference between the present example and the second example studied by Lee and Tsai [1] lies in the radius r. They found that the synthesized mechanism for their second example encountered a branch problem during motion where it is necessary to change its assembly condition. They inadvertently considered the circuit defect as the branch problem. The assembly condition of the branch defect does not need to be changed and may be excluded using a lateral perturbation force (or displacement). The author found that the problem (may be an order defect) encountered in their second example may arise from the radius r. Thus, the radius r of 7 is changed to 1.5.
Design variables: X= [x0, y0, θ0, L1, Lp, φ1, L41, θ41, θ42, θ43, θ44, θ45]
Limits of the variables:

The synthesized design variables and the objective function value are shown in Table 2. It can be seen that a very accurate result is obtained. The evolution of the objective function value of the best-so-far individual corresponding to the number of generations is shown in Fig. 4. Smaller objective function values for the other 10 repeated runs such as 2.61 × 10−12, 2.26 × 10−12, or 8.2 × 10− 13 may be obtained. The synthesized result for this example that appears in Table 2 is sufficiently accurate. The kinematic stick diagram for the five target points is shown in Fig. 5. The rolling of Link 3 from position 1 to position 3 is clockwise. There is a change in the direction of rolling between positions 3 and 4, because of L44 < L43. Figure 5
Kinematic stick diagram for Example 2

sec.title: 5.3 Synthesis of seven target points on a smooth curve
sec.p: This example with the radius r of 1.5 was studied by Lee and Tsai [1].
Design variables: X= [x0, y0, θ0, L1, Lp, φ1, L41, θ41, θ42, θ43, θ44, θ45, θ46, θ47]
Limits of the variables:

The synthesized design variables and the objective function value are shown in Table 2. The kinematic stick diagram for the five target points is shown in Fig. 6. The evolution of the objective function value of the best-so-far individual corresponding to the number of generations is shown in Fig. 4. The present result is more accurate than that obtained by Lee and Tsai [1] using the sequential quadratic programming algorithm. In fact, Lee and Tsai's formulation and the sequential quadratic programming algorithm used cannot solve a synthesis problem consisting of seven target points. Thus, the same smooth curve is used in this example as in the first example, while the two target points, i.e. (1.6627, 3.1630) and (−0.0223, 2.7773), between the second and third points and between the fourth and fifth points are increased to form the present seven-target-point problem. The 18 values of design variables obtained in the first example are used as the initial estimate for the seven-target-point problem. Under these conditions, only six more newly estimated values are needed to run the optimization procedure. In contrast, the present method does not need to use the synthesized results from the first example as an initial guess. The initial values of the design variables for the present method are randomly generated by computer code. Therefore, the present model is superior to the method proposed by Lee and Tsai [1]. Smaller objective function values for the other 50 repeated runs (e.g. 1.40 × 10− 6) may be obtained. A larger population size Np = 800 and/or a larger generation Gmax = 2000 may not lead to a much more accurate solution. The best synthesized results for all examples obtained in this work are shown in Table 3. Figure 6

sec.title: 6 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The kinematic synthesis formulation for the four-link mechanism with rolling contacts discussed in the literature complicates the problems due to an improper selection of the design variables, which leads to simultaneous increases in the number of design variables and in the number of synthesis equations. An improved formulation for the path synthesis of the four-link mechanism with rolling contacts is proposed. The GA–DE hybrid evolutionary algorithm is applied to solve the optimum path synthesis problem. Three examples are studied. With the present formulation, the number of design variables for the path synthesis problem with seven target points can be reduced by 10 when compared with that found using the previous formulation discussed in the literature. This reduces the difficulty of a seven-target-point synthesis problem. More satisfactory results can be obtained for all cases only with the GA–DE algorithm. Thus, the proposed formulation is superior to the previous one discussed in the literature.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
ack.p: The author would like to express the deepest appreciation to the Editor for the further review and to theanonymous reviewers for the constructive comments.
